Graphical abstract Methane dehydroaromatization is a potential technique in converting natural gas into value-added aromatics and clean hydrogen. However, severe coking hinders industrial application of conventionally prepared Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst for methane dehydroaromatization. Usually, Bronsted acid sites (BAS) were considered the key for coking. To gain deeper insight into the coke, here we present a simple post-impregnation of Na+ to Mo/HZSM-5 to regulate its surface acidity. Influences of BAS on catalytic performance and coking behavior were thus exclusively studied. Na+ modified catalysts exhibit lower naphthalene and higher C2 selectivity, while selectivity for benzene is not obviously changed. These results contradict conventional bi-functional pathway that methane is dehydrogenated on Mo while BAS act as the center for intermediates cyclization. Characterizations and calculations indicate restricted growth of hydrocarbon pools confined in zeolite channels of Na+ modified catalysts. Hence, it is proposed that aromatization is the intrinsic property of Mo, and the Mo-associated carbonaceous species act as precursors for both coke and aromatics production. Keywords Methane dehydroaromatization Mo/ZSM-5 Na+ post-impregnation Coking Mono-functional Hydrocarbon pool mechanism 1 Introduction Methane has the simplest structure among alkane molecules and is abundantly reserved in natural gas, shale gas and coal-bed gas. Its conversion into fuels and chemicals, such as ethane, ethylene and aromatics, is of great interest both in academic researches and practical applications. Earlier, direct aromatization of methane using zeolitic catalysts was pioneered by some Russian scientists [1,2]. Since 1993 Wang et al. [3] first reported that Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst could convert methane into aromatics with high selectivity, the methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) started to draw massive interests, and abundant research efforts were devoted to this promising technology. In addition, the main byproduct gas of MDA process is COx-free hydrogen, which is an ideal source of clean energy as well. Different factors concerning preparation method [4–13], calcination [14–16], post-treatment [17–23], reaction and regeneration conditions [24–27] and so on were investigated systematically and discussed in detail during the past 27 years. Till now, the Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst can give outstanding performance, which nearly reaches the thermodynamic limits of MDA reaction [28]. Nevertheless, the biggest obstacle in front is the inevitable coking, inhibiting large-scale application of Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst. Coke combustion is a conventional regeneration method, but it often results in irreversible activity loss due to the formation of inactive aluminum molybdate. Moreover, the frequent regeneration is highly energy-consuming and subsequent massive carbon emission may cause intractable climatic problems [16,29–31]. Thus, to deeply understand the nature of coke and effectively suppressing coking to improve catalyst stability are of great significance for MDA process. Most researchers agree that Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst in methane aromatization acts in a bi-functional way. Methane is first activated on the molybdenum carbide (or molybdenum oxy-carbide) species to form CHx fragments, which are then dimerized and cyclized on Bronsted acid sites (BAS) inside ZSM-5 channels to produce aromatics such as benzene and naphthalene [12,32,33]. Although this bi-functional reaction pathway has been widely accepted, the intrinsic MDA mechanism is still uncertain; especially, what is the true intermediate during the course, and how hydrocarbon species evolve inside zeolite channels? The latter is of great significance since it is usually considered as the key for coking. It was reported that there exist different types of coke on catalyst surface in the form of graphitic carbon, molybdenum carbides and poly-aromatic carbonaceous deposits [4,34–36]. The last type of coke species was believed to be highly associated with Bronsted acids and to be the main factor accounting for catalyst deactivation. However, totally removing the Bronsted acids to inhibit coke accumulation is not sensible, since these acid sites not only participate in the oligomerization of intermediates but also serve as the anchoring points for molybdenum during catalyst calcination. Iglesia et al. found that when treated in air at high temperature, MoOx at external surface of ZSM-5 would migrate into the channels and replace approximate 1.1 residual protons [37]. Podkolzin et al. studied the anchoring mode of molybdenum explicitly and revealed that MoOx preferentially anchored on the two adjacent Al atoms within the 10-member ring of ZSM-5 at low Si/Al ratio (such as Si/Al = 15) [33,38]. Thus, if one wants to exclusively investigate how BAS functions in this reaction and the mechanism of coking, it is crucial to carefully adjust the amount of Bronsted acids without affecting Mo dispersion. Measures such as adding alkali metals [39,40] and hydrothermal dealumination of ZSM-5 [20,21] were taken to suppress coking by eliminating excessive Bronsted acids. For example, Martínez et al. [39] investigated the quantitative matching of Bronsted acid sites and Mo loadings via partial exchange of ZSM-5 protons with alkali and alkaline-earth cations. It was found that for the monovalent cations (Na+, Cs+), the optimum exchange level of M+/Al is 0.1, while for the divalent cations (Mg2+, Ca2+), a M2+/Al of 0.05 is suitable with 3 wt% Mo loading on ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 15). This strategy can remarkably improve catalyst stability at the expense of partial activity. Moreover, it could also cause a less favored migration of Mo into zeolite channels, lowering the dispersion of active Mo phase [39]. The hydrothermal dealumination has similar problem, since the distribution of Al would be considerably altered, changing the dispersion of Mo-specie as well. As mentioned above, coke inside zeolite channels was usually considered detrimental as it blocks zeolite pores and covers active sites, preventing the contact between methane and active sites as reaction proceeds, and causes continuous deactivation. However, some researchers deeply investigated the role of coke deposition recently, especially the carbonaceous species formed during the induction period. They claimed that the function of such carbonaceous species inside zeolite channels may be underestimated previously and they may even play a vital role in generating aromatics [41–44]. By using methane pulsing technique and isotope labelled 13CO pre-carburization, Vollmer et al. found that C atoms entrapped by MoOxCy active phase during the induction period were incorporated into initially produced benzene molecules [43]. Kosinov et al. [41] used labelled 13CH4 to pretreat catalyst followed by using the normal methane. As a result, more than 70% benzene molecules produced were detected to contain at least one 13C atoms. Thus they proposed a novel mechanism that the carbonaceous species confined in ZSM-5 pores are the precursors for aromatic products, which is somewhat similar to the hydrocarbon pool mechanism widely accepted in methanol to olefins (MTO) process [45]. This unexpected aspect was further validated by other works [42,44], which make us to consider again what the coke really is and is it always a trouble for Mo/ZSM-5 MDA catalyst? To address this question, here we investigated the mechanism of coking via introducing Na+ to Mo/ZSM-5. Given that the amount and strength of Bronsted acids would affect the migration of Mo into ZSM-5 channels during calcination, conventional ion exchange of Na+ with H-ZSM-5 support to adjust surface acidity prior to Mo impregnation may also cause Mo dispersion change, especially at relatively high Na+ loadings. That means the dispersion of Mo and surface acidity are regulated simultaneously, which would both contribute to the change in catalytic performance. To exclusively discuss the sole influence of acidity variations without obviously changing Mo dispersion, we loaded Mo first via impregnation followed by calcination. Then Na+ was loaded also with impregnation method in a second step. Characterizations validated that this treatment could quantitatively regulate surface acidity with a very limited effect on Mo dispersion. These Na+ post-impregnated catalysts considerably lowered the coke amount confined in zeolite channels. Moreover, the benzene selectivity was not obviously changed, whereas the naphthalene selectivity was reduced and C2 selectivity was enhanced over these Na+ impregnated catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Na-ZSM-5 was supplied by Lanzhou Catalyst Plant, CNPC, with a Si/Al ratio of 15. Prior to use, a typical ammonium exchange was conducted twice to obtain protonated form. In brief, 10 g of Na-ZSM-5 was added into 100 mL NH4Cl (Sinopharm) solution (1 mol/L) and stirred for 4 h at 85 °C. Then the mixture was washed and dried at 110 °C overnight, followed by calcination at 550 °C for 4 h. After ammonium exchange the H-ZSM-5 was impregnated with certain amount of (NH4)6Mo7O24 (Sinopharm) solutions. Then the mixture was dried overnight at 110 °C and then calcined at 550 °C for 4 h to obtain Mo/ZSM-5. In the following, the Mo/ZSM-5 was divided into different portions. For each portion, NaNO3 solutions with different concentration were added to impregnate Na+, followed by the same drying and calcination procedure mentioned above. Final catalysts were denoted as SMx SNy, while x and y represent molar ratio of Si/Mo and Si/Na in the feeding recipe, respectively. For reference, another portion of Mo/ZSM-5 was impregnated with bare deionized water instead of NaNO3 solutions to make sure this sample was treated with same conditions only without Na+ loading. This sodium free sample was denoted as SMx, in which x represents feeding Si/Mo ratio. All catalysts were tableted and crushed into 20–40 mesh for further catalytic evaluations. 2.2 Evaluation of catalysts in methane dehydroaromatization (MDA) Catalysts were evaluated in a continuous-flow fixed-bed micro-reactor (Effi, Micromeritics Inc.). For each test, 0.5 g of catalyst was packed in the middle of a 316 stainless steel tube (length of 500 mm, diameter of 10 mm and thickness of 3 mm), with a thermocouple inserted into the middle of catalyst bed. During pre-heating procedure, 15 mL/min Ar flow was injected from the top of the reaction tube and the oven temperature was raised to 700 °C with a ramp rate of 15 °C/min. After pre-heating the gas flow was switched to 90 vol.% CH4/N2 mixture with a flow rate of 15 mL/min. Reactor outlet pipeline and gas chromatograph (GC) valves were heated to 160 °C to avoid possible products condensation. N2 was used as internal standard and all products were analyzed by an online GC (Scion 456, Techcomp Co. Ltd). CH4, N2, H2, CO, CO2, C2H4 and C2H6 were separated by Hayesep T and Hayesep Q columns and detected by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). CH4 and aromatics including C6H6, C7H8 and C10H10 were separated by a 13X capillary column and detected by flame ionization detector (FID). Conversion of methane, yield and selectivity of main products were calculated based on carbon atom balance. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations Elemental composition of catalysts was obtained with inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) on a Perkin Elmer Optima 8000 instrument. Prior to each test, 50 mg samples were dissolved in a 3 mL HF, 0.125 mL HNO3 and 0.375 mL HCl mixed solutions. Excessive HF was saturated with boric acid to avoid corrosion of combustion chamber of the instrument. Phase analysis was conducted with powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) on an Empyrean diffractometer (PANalytical B.V.) equipped with Bragg-Brentano HD light source and Pixcel 3D detector. Working voltage and current were 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively. The scanning step size was 0.013° and the scanning speed was set as 10 s per step. Diffraction patterns were recorded in the 2θ range of 5° to 75°. UV–vis spectra were recorded on a SPECORD 210 plus (Analytik Jena) spectrometer in the range of 200−800 nm. BaSO4 was mixed with samples as both diluter and white standard. High angle annular dark field - scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM, Talos, FEI) together with energy dispersive spectra were used to observe surface Mo dispersion. The working voltage was set as 200 kV. Acidity variations of catalysts after Na+ addition were determined by pyridine diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transformed spectroscopy (Py-DRIFTS) and ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). Prior to Py-DRIFTS measurements, all catalysts were dried at 300 °C for 3 h. After that they were adsorbed with pyridine for 24 h until saturation. In the following, catalysts were further heated at 150 °C under vacuum for 3 h to remove physically absorbed pyridine. Samples treated with same procedure except for pyridine adsorption were used to record background. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 6700 (Thermo Fisher) infrared spectrometer. NH3-TPD was conducted also on an AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics) equipped with TCD. About 0.1 g catalyst (20–40 mesh) was packed in the middle of a U-shaped quartz tube. Before analyzing, the samples were outgassed in an Ar flow (80 mL/min) at 300 °C for 2 h. After cooling down to 80 °C, samples were saturated with 20 vol% NH3/He with a flow rate of 25 mL/min for 40 min. Then 50 mL/min of N2 was fed to remove physically adsorbed NH3. Temperature was elevated from 50 °C to 700 °C under N2 flow to obtain TPD profiles. Coke combustion of spent catalysts was analyzed by thermogravimetry-mass spectroscopy (TG-MS) which was conducted on a 209 F3 TG-MS system (Netzsch) under air flow. The MS was used to record released carbon dioxide during burning process at m/z = 44. Raman spectra were obtained from a LabRAM Raman spectrophotometer (HORIBA Jobin Yvon) in the powder form. Spectra were record at ambient temperature with an excitation source of 532 nm. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) data were collected from an ESCALAB 250Xi analyzer (Thermo Fisher) with a monochromatic Al Kα radiation. The total acquisition time is 5.25 min. The pass energy and energy step size were set as 30.0 eV and 0.10 eV, respectively. Binding energies were referenced to C 1S at 284.8 eV. Peak fitting was conducted with XPSPEAK 41 program. 2.4 Computational details and ZSM-5 model descriptions All calculations were performed in the DMol3 module of Materials Studio 8.0 software (Accelrys Inc., now BIOVIA) [46,47]. Meta generalized gradient approximation (m-GGA) in the M06-L parameterization [48] and double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set were used in the calculations. The convergence tolerances were set as 5 × 10−3 Å for displacement, 2 × 10−3 Ha/Å for gradient, and 1 × 10−5 hartree for total energy, respectively. Brillouin-zone integrations were selected with a Methfessel-Paxton smearing of 5 × 10−3 Ha. The zero-point vibrational energy correction have been considered in these calculations. Adsorption energy was calculated as: Ea = Eads+cat - Eads - Ecat Where Ea , Eads+cat , Eads and Ecat represents the adsorption energy of adsorbate, total energy of the adsorbate on the catalyst, gas phase adsorbate energy and energy of bare catalyst, respectively. The cluster models of ZSM-5 were constructed at the intersection of the 10-membered-ring straight channels and sinusoidal channels. A 34 T model is used to represent the HZSM-5, which contains a complete straight channel and a sinusoidal channel to reflect the confinement effect of the pore structure. T12 position locating at the intersection of these two type channels was chosen as the most possible framework Al site to replace Si atom, which is widely reported previously [49,50]. The corresponding H proton or Na+ cation is located on the oxygen atom between the two T12 sites. To ensure the consistency of the framework, H protons are used to saturate dangling bonds previously connected to the selected Si-O model in the 34 T model. During geometric optimization, destruction of the channel structure is forced to be avoided. 8 T model of the relaxation is chosen to be the active region, and the rest part was fixed at the original unit cell position to shorten calculation time and prevent collapse of the channel structure. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Retainment of Mo-species states after Na+ addition As mentioned above, a bi-functional pathway in MDA reaction has been widely accepted, in which both Mo states and surface acidic properties essentially affect the catalyst performance. To exclusively investigate the influence of BAS variation on catalytic performance, we employed post-impregnation of Na+ (instead of a conventional Na+ pre-exchange) to the H-ZSM-5 support, attempting to minimize the possible change in Mo dispersion during calcination. Thus, the retainment of Mo-species states before and after Na+ introduction should be verified first. Herein, the SM35 series catalysts are taken as an example. The elemental composition of SM35 series catalysts are measured first with ICP-OES to verify the amount of introduced Mo or Na amount is accurate. Detailed results are listed in Table 1 . For all the four catalysts, the Mo mass content is about 4.1 (± 0.1) wt%, which means the impregnated Mo amount is nearly constant. The Na mass content in pristine SM35 is only 0.02 wt%, proving that the ammonium exchange with commercial Na-ZSM-5 support to obtain H-ZSM-5 is almost thorough. After intentionally introducing Na+, the Na amount augments considerably to 0.36 wt% for SM35 SN90. Further increasing the amount of impregnated Na+ amplifies the measured Na+ content to c.a. 1.5-fold (SM35 SN60, Na+: 0.59 wt%) and 2-fold (SM35 SN45, Na+: 0.69 wt%) as that in SM35 SN90 (0.36 wt%), which reach the values as anticipated. Thus the ICP-OES results confirm that both Mo and Na amount is accurate in our preparation. XRD patterns of SM35 series catalysts are shown in Fig. S1. For all catalysts, characteristic ZSM-5 peaks are presented at 2θ = 7.9°, 8.8°, 23.0°, 23.9° and 24.3°. No obvious decline could be observed in the relative crystallinity after introducing Na+ (Table 1). Typical α-MoO3 peaks at 2θ = 12.9°, 33.7° and 39.0° was not detected for both SM35 and its Na+ impregnated counterparts, suggesting a good dispersion of Mo-species [27]. The Mo state was also probed by the UV–vis and Raman spectra, with the spectra shown in Fig. 1 . Bandgap (λg), determined by the intersection of the sloping and horizontal parts of the spectra [51,52], is known to mirror the coordination environment of Mo oxides [53,54]. It could be observed first that the UV–vis spectra (Fig. 1a) for all the four catalysts exhibit almost the same slope, which intersects with the X axis at 386 nm. Nearly the same bandgap of SM35 and its Na+ impregnated counterparts proves that the coordination state of Mo-oxide species remains basically unchanged regardless of the introduction of Na+. Then the bandgap energy (Eg) is calculated based on the equation of Eg = 1240/λg as well [55,56], and the obtained value of 3.2 eV is close to the reported value of 3.5 eV on Mo/H-ZSM-5 with comparable Mo loading amount [30,57]. Of note is that a tiny adsorption band swells up at ca. 400 nm in SM35 SN60 and SM35 SN45, which may indicate formation of small portion of polymeric Mo species [58]. The catalysts were then subjected to Raman technique with spectra shown in Fig. 1 b. All samples exhibit distinct bands at 373, 813, 867 and 953 cm−1. The first band at 373 cm−1 is characteristic of the double-five-ring vibration of MFI framework [59]. The bands at 813 and 867 cm-1 are attributed to the asymmetric stretching mode of Mo-O-Mo, and band at 953 cm−1 is ascribed to the symmetric stretching mode of terminal Mo = O bond in polymerized (Mo7O24)6+ species, respectively [60]. Compared with the intensity of ZSM-5 framework at 373 cm−1, the intensity of the bands at 813 and 953 cm−1 is almost unchanged after loading Na+, while the intensity of the band at 867 cm−1 declines slightly. Previously some researchers assign the 867 cm−1 band to [Mo2O5]2+ anchored on BAS [61]. These results suggest a slight, partial Mo migration to external zeolite surface. Thus the Raman spectra confirm that the introduction of Na+ slightly decrease the dispersion of Mo, but the impact is limited. Elemental dispersion is also shown by HAADF-STEM and XPS. From Fig. 2 it could be observed that Mo is uniformly dispersed on both parent SM35 and Na+ loaded counterparts (SM35 SN45). XPS surface Mo/(Si + Al) atomic ratio (Table 1) is 0.19, 0.22 and 0.21 for SM35, SM35 SN60 and SM35 SN45, respectively. The slight increase in surface Mo content thus indicates that after the post-impregnation of Na+, Mo species show a slight migration to zeolite surface, but the total dispersion change is limited. This agrees with above UV–vis and Raman results. Hence, based on the above characterizations, it could be concluded that stabilizing Mo first, followed by post-impregnation of Na+, is an effective measure to avoid the Mo dispersion change as far as possible. Though complete intactness of Mo could not be achieved experimentally, via the Na+ post-impregnation we could minimize the effect of Na+ on Mo dispersion, especially when compared with conventional Na+ exchange of ZSM-5 support before loading Mo. 3.2 Acidity regulations via Na+ modification Above characterizations in section 3.1 has proved that via the post-impregnation, the impact of Na+ on Mo-species states could be remarkably diluted. Therefore, it could be deemed that Mo states did not change after introducing Na+ and we could exclusively investigate the influence of acidic properties variation on catalytic performance. Prior to the evaluation of catalysts, their acidity after Na+ modification should be measured first. The acidic properties of the SM35 series catalysts and H-ZSM-5 support were examined by NH3-TPD technique, and the TPD profiles are shown in Fig. 3 a. After loading Mo on H-ZSM-5 support, the desorption peak intensity at high temperature (of about 410 °C) of SM35 is slashed compared with that of pure H-ZSM-5, indicating the anchoring of Mo on framework Al (namely the strong acid sites) of H-ZSM-5 [62,63]. Considering the optimal anchoring mode of Mo on an Al pair proposed by Podkolzin et al. [33,38,64], an Al/Mo molar ratio of 2 can be expected, which is still smaller than the real Al/Mo of 2.33 in the SM35 (Si/Al = 15, Si/Mo = 35) catalysts. Thus, doping a few amount of Na+ would neutralize the rest acid sites. Further increasing the amount of Na+ would lead to successive but unremarkable diminishment in the intensity of strong acid peak, which suggests that the framework Al sites are almost totally occupied by Na+ and the rest is hard to access. Indeed, with the addition of Na+ to the catalysts from SM35 to SM35 SN90, another conspicuous decline in this strong acid peak is observed, while further increasing Na+ amount result in a milder decline in the peak intensity. Acidity variations are convinced by Py-DRIFTS (Fig. 3 b andTable S1) as well. Concentration of BAS (Bronsted acid sites) and LAS (Lewis acid sites) were calculated according to the areas of the peaks at 1546 cm−1 and 1447 cm−1,based on the method proposed by Emeis et al. [65]. The BAS concentration of H-ZSM-5 support was set as 100% and the value of its LAS and acidic concentration of other SM35 series catalysts were normalized accordingly. As shown in Table S1, loading Mo causes both remarkable decline in the BAS and LAS of HZSM-5, suggesting the anchoring of Mo on both framework and extra-framework Al sites. With the Na+ addition, BAS content further decreases from 57% (SM35) to 44% (SM35 SN90), while the decrease in LAS is much more inconspicuous (from 17% to 16%). This phenomenon implies that the introduction of Na+ mainly neutralizes the BAS of the catalysts, which is consistent with NH3-TPD that Na+preferably locates on framework Al sites (strong acid sites). Promoting Na+ content causes BAS reduction from 44% (SM35 SN90) to 39% (SM35 SN45) and LAS reduction from 16% (SM35 SN90) to 14% (SM35 SN45), leading to an almost constant B/L ratio of 2.8. This is also in line with above NH3-TPD results that the rest of BAS is hard to access by Na+. Thus, based on these NH3-TPD and Py-DRIFTS analyses, we believe that the post-impregnation of Na+ could quantitatively regulate the surface acidity of the Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst active for methane aromatization. 3.3 Catalytic performance Sections 3.1 and 3.2 have validated that Na+ post-impregnation is an efficient measure to quantitatively regulate surface acidity with limited impact on Mo states or dispersion. Hence, now it is possible to evaluate the influence of sole BAS change on catalytic performance for MDA reaction. Before catalyst evaluation, a blank experiment containing no catalysts was conducted to rule out catalytic contributions from stainless steel wall of the reactor tube. The conversion of CH4 is only 2% and the product is totally coke (Fig. S2), proving that the blank tube does not catalyze the MDA process. To illustrate performance variations before and after Na+ impregnation, the SM35 series samples with different Na+ loadings were tested. CH4 conversion of the catalysts is shown in Fig. 4 a. All samples exhibit the similar trend that the CH4 conversion starts to drop gradually from 20 min on stream. The (Na+-free) SM35 sample exhibits the highest conversion, while the samples with amplified Na+ doping amount give the continuously declined average conversion. Na+ impregnation also influences aromatics selectivity. All catalysts show a typical induction period in the earlier 120 min, during which the selectivity to benzene (Fig. 4b) and naphthalene (Fig. S3) gradually increases until reaching the climax. After this period, benzene selectivity maintains almost unchanged till 600 min on stream, while naphthalene selectivity drops slowly. Increasing Na+ doping amount leads to a slight decrease in benzene selectivity (Fig. 4b, from 39% of SM35 to 32% of SM35 SN45), while naphthalene selectivity is dramatically hindered with the addition of Na+ (Fig. S3). For example, the maximum naphthalene selectivity of SM35 SN45 is about only half of that of SM35. To compare aromatics selectivity more directly, curves representing benzene/naphthalene selectivity ratio are plotted as a function of time on stream (TOS), and it is shown that all catalysts exhibit similar trend in this ratio (Fig. 4c). During the induction period, this ratio for all catalysts is reduced with TOS, indicating the favorable formation of heavier products. At about 80 min, this ratio reaches minimum and starts to rise, giving less naphthalene. On the other hand, ben/naph ratio aggrandizes consecutively with Na+ amount, suggesting the formation of heavier products is inhibited to a different extent. Figs. S4 and S5 show the ben/naph ratio of SM40 and SM45 series catalysts with different Na+ amount, in which the tendencies coincide with Fig. 4 c. To summarize, the influence of Na+ addition on naphthalene production is much more pronounced than on benzene. Moreover, increasing Na+ amount also favors C2 (mainly ethylene) selectivity (Table 2 and Fig. 4d), under the circumstance that all catalysts exhibit similarly total hydrocarbon selectivity (Table 2 and Fig. S6). 3.4 Coking resistance via sole acidity regulation As manifested above that via post Na+ impregnation, the acidity of Mo/ZSM-5 catalysts could be tuned quantitatively without obvious change in the Mo-species dispersion. Hence, the coking behavior in MDA reaction of catalysts before and after introducing Na+ is further investigated, since the acid sites were usually deemed to be the main reason for coking and catalyst deactivation [4,34–36]. A series of techniques were applied to characterize the coke formed over the catalysts. Fresh and spent catalysts were probed by XRD to compare phase variation before and after reaction (Fig. S7). After MDA reaction, ZSM-5 structure was also well preserved with slightly lessened peak intensity, which may result from the as-formed coke on zeolite surface [66]. Thermogravimetry analyses were conducted to investigate the combustion of surface coke species. All spent catalysts (at TOS =600 min) exhibit coke combustion at similar temperature but with different weight loss (Fig. 5 a). The weight loss for all catalysts starts from about 420 °C and ends at about 610 °C. Total coke amount of spent SM35 were calculated accordingly to be 3.4%; with the augment of Na+, coke amount of spent catalysts dropped gradually to 2.0% for SM35 SN45. Specifically, this weight loss stage was divided into three regions, which could be further confirmed by three distinct signals in DSC (Fig. 5b) or DTG (Fig. 5c) profiles. The lower temperature region (440−470 °C) was attributed to the combustion of MoCx/MoOxCy coke or coke on external surface of zeolites; the middle temperature region (480−500 °C) was assigned to the coke formed on the pore mouth of ZSM-5; while higher temperature region (500−650 °C) was attributed to poly-aromatic carbonaceous species generated deep within the zeolite channels [31,39,66,67]. To gain a deeper insight into the nature of the coke, CO2 released by coke combustion was also recorded concurrently via mass spectroscopy and shown in Fig. 5 d. Of note is that CO emission is not presented here since negligible CO signal was detected during the test, indicating that almost complete combustion of coke was achieved. All CO2 profiles were fitted into three peaks according to DTG and DSC exothermal signals and details are listed in Table S2. With increasing Na+ content, the low temperature CO2 emission peak slightly shifts from 441 °C (spent SM35) to 465 °C (spent SM35 SN45), and the middle temperature peak shifts slightly from 479 °C (spent SM35) to 498 °C (spent SM35 SN45). On the other hand, the position of high temperature CO2 emission peak remains unchanged. Since this higher combustion temperature is mainly caused by limited oxygen diffusion to the constrained ZSM-5 channels, the unchanged position of this peak indicates a similar pore blockage manner of poly-aromatic carbonaceous species despite the introduction of Na+ [42]. Furthermore, contents of this high temperature coke dwindle continuously as elevating Na+ amount. Accordingly, the decline of carbonaceous species filling zeolite pores should be originated from the neutralization of framework Al with Na+ introduction, since the Mo states were almost not affected by Na+ doping. Raman spectroscopy is a sensitive tool to determine the types and amount of surface carbon species, and the spectra of spent SM35 series catalysts are shown in Fig. 6 . Bands at approximately 1400 cm−1 and 1580 cm−1 are usually ascribed to disorder-induced planes of graphite and ordered in-plane sp2 vibration of graphite, respectively, which are also known as D band and G band [68–70]. It can be seen that spent Na+-free SM35 catalyst exhibits a relatively sharper G band. After introducing Na+, the intensity of G band decreases. The maximum intensity of D (ID) and G (IG) bands was measured (Table S3). The parameter ID/IG reflects the disorder degree of surface graphite-like coke [71,72]. ID/IG for SM35 is about 0.53, which increases to about 0.7 of SM35 SN45 after Na+ additions, indicating a more disordered nature of surface carbon species. This is in line with CO2 emission profiles that Na+ introduction resulted in an abatement of poly-aromatic carbonaceous species inside the channels. 3.5 Nature to coke-resistance and selectivity-regulation after Na+ addition 3.5.1 Bi-functional or mono-functional mechanism? According to the conventional bi-functional mechanism, BAS is involved in the cyclization and aromatization of C2 intermediates in the MDA reaction. Nevertheless, doubts were raised on whether the BAS is necessary in this reaction, or that the real MDA mechanism may be a mono-functional manner [73–76]. Kosinov et al. loaded Mo on non-acidic Silicalite-1 (Mo/S-1) zeolite and it displayed a maximum benzene yield of 3% in MDA reaction [75]. Though this value is much lower than 12% of the Mo/ZSM-5 possessing BAS, it still evoked the possibility that BAS may not be a prerequisite in MDA reaction. Beale et al. attributed the lower benzene yield of Mo/S-1 to severe agglomeration of Mo-species on external zeolite surface, which could not take advantages of the selective zeolite channels [76]. Since S-1 lacks framework Al, it could not provide sufficient anchoring points for the migration of external Mo-species into the pores. In order to improve Mo dispersion, they generated silanol groups via framework Si extraction, thus Mo atoms could be captured via strengthened Mo-support interactions. Under this circumstance the modified Mo/S-1 catalyst exhibited comparable benzene yield as conventional Mo/ZSM-5. Both researches unambiguously evidenced that aromatization is an intrinsic property of Mo sites, while BAS maybe not necessary in this reaction. It has been discussed in section 3.2 that the rest framework Al sites of catalysts could be quantitatively saturated by Na+. If the bi-functional mechanism fits our Na+-regulated catalysts, the aromatics production should be remarkably suppressed with the gradual or even complete neutralization of BAS, since BAS is usually considered to be the aromatization center for C2 intermediates. However, the benzene selectivity was not significantly influenced in the present catalytic evaluations (Table 2). Situation for naphthalene is somewhat worse, but its selectivity for SM35 SN45 (6.8%) still keeps about 48% as that of SM35 (14.3%). These changes of products distribution (especially for the almost unchanged benzene selectivity) quite contradict the previously proposed aromatization functions of BAS if an analogy to hydride transfer or protolysis mechanism is applied [77]. Thus, the preserved aromatic selectivity further convinced that Mo (to be more specific, carbidic or oxy-carbidic Mo) itself is of intrinsic ability to convert methane into aromatics directly. BAS mainly acts as the driving force for the migration and dispersion of Mo sites inside zeolite channels, while its role in the aromatization step may be exaggerated previously. Moreover, a recent research by Vollmer et al. further revealed that ethylene may not be the true intermediate as it was usually considered [78]. The direct feed of ethylene to HZSM-5 did not achieve desired catalytic performance as conventional Mo/ZSM-5 in MDA reaction. Even though the Mo/ZSM-5 (Si/Al = 15) has almost the same acidity as pure HZSM-5 (Si/Al = 40), the aromatic yield for Mo/ZSM-5 is much higher [78]. Furthermore, Julian et al. observed a surprisingly high yield of acetylene under micro-wave heated and high spatial velocity conditions [79]. It was attributed to the C–H activation on highly isolated Mo sites formed via the help of micro-wave radiation, which indicated that C2H2 may be the initial intermediate while ethylene and benzene are generated as secondary products. In addition, heavy aromatics were considerably reduced. Above findings again verified the irreplaceable contributions of Mo sites and limited participation of BAS during aromatization steps. 3.5.2 Confined carbonaceous species However, if BAS is restrictedly involved or completely a spectator in the MDA process, why does the methane conversion show a gradual decline instead of being constant as increasing Na+ amount? As has been envisaged recently [41,42], the reaction pathway of MDA on Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst is in analogy to the hydrocarbon pool (HCP) mechanism in methanol-to-olefin reaction [41,43,44]. Accordingly, intermediates generated from methane dehydrogenation on Mo sites are the precursors for producing benzene. Nevertheless, they do not cyclize directly to form light aromatics (i.e. benzene, naphthalene), but are prone to accumulate and grow to polycyclic aromatic pools. These polycyclic HCPs get increasingly unstable as adding phenyl rings, and thus gradually decompose when reaching certain chain length and release light aromatics as final products. Given that aromatic pools are formed prior to the generation of gas phase benzene molecules, in this study, Na+ addition would surely result in a constrained space for hydrocarbon pool growth, leading to lower amount of more inert carbonaceous species confined in zeolite channels. This is validated by the consecutively dwindled high-temperature coke amount from spent SM35 to SM35 SN45, as shown in TG-MS (Fig. 5) and Raman (Fig. 6) analyses. Based on above results and analyses, we propose that introducing Na+ causes not only neutralization of framework Al, but also more steric constraints to the growth of HCP. These lead to the reverse of the kinetic equilibrium and continuously decreased methane conversions (Fig. 4a). It was reported in the literature that linear growth of HCP confined in the zeolite channels is the most possible manner for coking [41]. We calculated adsorption energy of benzene, naphthalene and anthracene on the sinusoidal channel of H-ZSM-5 and Na-ZSM-5 respectively (models are shown in Fig. S8-S11), and the results are listed in Table 3 . With adding more phenyl rings, the adsorption energy of aromatics on both H-ZSM-5 and Na-ZSM-5 becomes larger, meaning that the adsorption of aromatic HCP is firmer, in which case that bigger HCP are more likely to be activated and decompose [78]. This is consistent with the catalytic performance that light benzene is more easily to be released than heavy naphthalene, leading to a ben/naph selectivity higher than 5/3 (ideal ratio of transforming 30 carbon atoms to 5 benzene or to 3 naphthalene molecules with equal possibility). On the other hand, differences between H-ZSM-5 and Na-ZSM-5 in the adsorption energy were also calculated for benzene and naphthalene, respectively. The decline of benzene adsorption energy is 19.2% from H-ZSM-5 to Na-ZSM-5, while for naphthalene the difference is 22.7%, slightly higher than benzene. This means that with the addition of Na+, the increase in the possibility of naphthalene desorption should be a little bit higher than that of benzene desorption, leading to slightly lower ben/naph value. However, the truth in our catalysts is that ben/naph was boosted remarkably as introducing Na+. Therefore, these quite opposite results between the calculated adsorption energy and practical catalytic performance evidenced that naphthalene release is hindered due to much suppressed formation with the addition of Na+, despite that naphthalene is more easily desorbed according to the calculation results. Considering the steric occupancy of Na+, the formation of larger hydrocarbon pool should be limited to some extent during MDA reaction. It would have much more pronounced impacts on the release of larger naphthalene than on that of smaller benzene molecule. This is also corroborated by an enhanced C2 selectivity (Fig. 4 d and Table 2). According to the kinetic equilibrium, the decrease in naphthalene selectivity by a restricted HCP growth would be compensated by an improved selectivity to ethylene, since all catalysts from SM35 to SM35 SN45 displayed almost identical total hydrocarbon selectivity (Fig. S6 and Table 2). 3.5.3 Enhanced production of smaller molecules The enhanced C2 selectivity can be further explained by Mo 3d XPS study on spent catalysts, showing that Na+ modified catalysts possess more active carbidic Mo sites. To precisely discriminate oxidation states of Mo-species on spent catalysts, a binding energy difference of 3.13 eV between Mo 3d3/2 and Mo 3d5/2 was applied. All peaks were deconvoluted into eight individual sub-peaks [80–82]. For the spent SM35 catalyst (Fig. 7 a), typical Mo 3d3/2 and Mo 3d5/2 sharp peaks could be seen at binding energy of 235.8 eV and 232.7 eV, respectively, which represent hexavalent Mo (Mo(VI)) and account for 87% of surface Mo-species. In addition, a small shoulder peak emerges at 228.3 eV and occupies 9% of total Mo-species, which could be designated to divalent Mo (Mo(II)). It was reported that Mo remaining at the external surface of zeolites is mainly hexa- and pentavalent, while Mo in di-valence is usually associated with carbidic or oxy-carbidic molybdenum species (MoOxCy) inside zeolite channels [43,83–85]. These molybdenum (oxy-) carbides are claimed to be the real active sites in activating methane and dimerizing CHx intermediates [86–89]. After introducing Na+, contents of Mo(VI) decreased sharply from 87% (spent SM35) to 30% (spent SM35 SN45), and Mo(II) amounts augmented significantly from 9% (spent SM35) to 53% (spent SM35 SN45), respectively. This means that catalysts modified by Na+ presents more active Mo-species. However, the enhancement of active Mo-species after introducing Na+ seems to be contradictory to the decrease in methane conversion (Fig. 4a). This is not exceptional, since it has been explained above that the growth of hydrocarbon pool confined inside zeolite channels is significantly obstructed by the occupation of Na+ on framework Al sites. Even though more active molybdenum (oxy-) carbides are formed by the induction of Na+, subsequently as-generated active CHx fragments could not interact with sufficient HCP to free them from the pores to release aromatics, leading to a reverse in the HCP to aromatics converting equilibrium. This not only diminishes methane conversion but also forces excessive CHx to couple, generating more C2 products including ethane and ethylene, as convinced by higher C2 selectivity of Na+ modified catalysts (Fig. 4d). 3.5.4 Role of Na+ Based on above results and analyses, the roles of Na+ could be interpreted as follows. After introducing Na+, the framework Al sites of the zeolites are partially or totally neutralized. This would cause more steric constraints for the growth of aromatic hydrocarbon pools inside zeolite channels during the contact with methane. The not fully grown HCP is subsequently activated by CHx intermediates derived from methane dehydrogenation, leading to the favored production of lighter hydrocarbons (C2 and benzene) and suppressed formation of naphthalene, regardless of more (oxy-) carbidic Mo sites are generated in Na+ modified catalysts during MDA reaction. The limited HCP is also reflected by less aromatic-like carbonaceous species inside the zeolite channels detected by TG-MS. BAS mainly acts as the anchoring points for Mo oxides during calcination, but is much less involved in the practical reaction, especially in the aromatization step that we usually deemed. 4 Conclusions In this study, post impregnation of Na+ to H-ZSM-5 instead of conventional ion exchange was applied, in order to retain the Mo dispersion during catalysts preparation as far as possible. Based on this exclusive and quantitative regulation of surface acidity, coking behavior was investigated since BAS was usually believed to be the main reason for coking and deactivation. It is displayed that higher Na+ contents resulted in lower coke deposition amount within zeolite channels, indicating a suppressed formation of larger hydrocarbon pool. Moreover, it is also demonstrated that the addition of Na+ has more significant influence on naphthalene selectivity than on benzene, and leads to higher selectivity to C2. Combining with the calculation of adsorption behavior, we further verified that this is caused by limited generation of larger hydrocarbon pool rather than inhibited desorption. Bronsted acids predominantly serve as the anchoring points for the dispersion of Mo-species, but their participation in aromatization step is quite limited, since neutralization of BAS did not lead to noteworthy decline in benzene selectivity. XPS results also showed that after introducing Na+, more divalent active Mo-species was generated during MDA reaction, contributing to the formation of more C2 products. Thus aromatization is supposed to be the intrinsic property of (oxy-) carbidic Mo sites, which is contrary to the conventional bi-functional pathway that methane is dehydrogenated on Mo and then dimerized and cyclized on BAS. Therefore, via Na+ post-impregnation, we presented a deeper understanding on the mechanism of methane dehydroaromatization, which would bring more inspirations for further research as well as catalyst design and modification on this potential reaction. coredata.dc:description: Methane dehydroaromatization is a potential technique in converting natural gas into value-added aromatics and clean hydrogen. However, severe coking hinders industrial application of conventionally prepared Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst for methane dehydroaromatization. Usually, Bronsted acid sites (BAS) were considered the key for coking. To gain deeper insight into the coke, here we present a simple post-impregnation of Na+ to Mo/HZSM-5 to regulate its surface acidity. Influences of BAS on catalytic performance and coking behavior were thus exclusively studied. Na+ modified catalysts exhibit lower naphthalene and higher C2 selectivity, while selectivity for benzene is not obviously changed. These results contradict conventional bi-functional pathway that methane is dehydrogenated on Mo while BAS act as the center for intermediates cyclization. Characterizations and calculations indicate restricted growth of hydrocarbon pools confined in zeolite channels of Na+ modified catalysts. Hence, it is proposed that aromatization is the intrinsic property of Mo, and the Mo-associated carbonaceous species act as precursors for both coke and aromatics production.
coredata.dc:title: Coking mechanism of Mo/ZSM-5 catalyst in methane dehydroaromatization
